pull.title: test: allow all functional tests to be run or skipped with --usecli
pull.body:
Fixes #32264

I looked into all current failures listed in the issue, there are several reasons why existing tests fail  with `--usecli` on many systems, the most important ones are:
- an empty string is returned by the cli - fixed by #32286
- There is a large RPC call that `execve` doesn't support (the limit is 128kb on my ubuntu system): Disabled these tests for now for the cli via `self.supports_cli = False`. One idea for a fix would be to add an option `-rpcfromfile` to `bitcoin-cli` that would allow us to read the full command from a (possibly temporary) file instead of passing it directly - this could be used by the functional test framework, but might be useful in general for people who want to use the cli instead of the rpc interface. Any opinions on this?
- Some functional test submits wrong types to params on purpose to test the error message (which is different when using the cli) - deactivated these specific subtests locally for the cli, since this is usually just a small independent part of the test.
- fixed some tests directly:
e.g. the `height_or_hash` param used in some RPC needs extra quotes if invoked with a hash from the cli, so that it isn't interpreted as a number.


Still in draft, outstanding ToDos (beyond looking into the bitcoin-cli change mentioned above) are:
- Check the instances of `self.supports_cli = False` existing on master if they are still necessary / can be fixed easily.
- Look deeper into `wallet_send.py`

<details><summary>Hints</summary>

Try to run the tests locally, according to the documentation. However, a CI failure may still
happen due to a number of reasons, for example:

* Possibly due to a silent merge conflict (the changes in this pull request being
incompatible with the current code in the target branch). If so, make sure to rebase on the latest
commit of the target branch.

* A sanitizer issue, which can only be found by compiling with the sanitizer and running the
  affected test.

* An intermittent issue.

Leave a comment here, if you need help tracking down a confusing failure.

</details>

events.message: test: fix rpc_deprecated.py to be usable with --usecli

test: add function that adds full quotes to string for height_or_hash params

For bitcoin-cli this is necessary, because a hash passed to the arg
which can be a number or a string would be interpreted as a number.

test: skip subtests that check for wrong types with cli

The error messages returned for wrong type differ betwen
using rpc or cli - skip these subtests where they happen.

test: Disable subtest using null characters for cli

Null characters cannot be passed to subprocess.Popen, which
is used for the bitcoin-cli commands.

test: set supports_cli = false for several tests

Reason for each test:
wallet_labels.py: uses createmultiwallet, which is currently not
compatible with cli
rpc_whitelist.py: Relies on direct RPC calls
wallet_send.py: TODO

test: Disable tests for cli that make large RPC calls

These tests send off large rpc calls (e.g.by submitting large txns or blocks)
that exceed the limit of execve (128kb on many systems) when using cli.

events.body: If this ends up fixing all issues, should add `--usecli` to atleast one CI, so we catch regressions?

> If this ends up fixing all issues, should add --usecli to atleast one CI, so we catch regressions?

Yes - it'd be a bit of  a waste of a CI job if we end up disabling too many of the tests with `self.supports_cli = False` but depending on how many can be fixed (I'm currently still going through all the existing disabled tests) that would make sense to me.

     test_framework.wait_until(lambda: node.getindexinfo("txindex")["txindex"]["synced"])
     test_framework.log.debug(f"Synced in {time.time() - sync_start} seconds")

comments.body:
q in 1c2ea560300f57e6b5ed75dee2597ca55dd76c6f: Would it not be easier if this was auto-detected? That is, if the type is string, would it not be better to internally (before dispatching to the cli) add quotes to all strings?

This probably means that numbers must be passed as `int`, or `Decimal` on the python side, which seems fine.

comments.diff_hunk:
@@ -603,3 +603,8 @@ def sync_txindex(test_framework, node):
     sync_start = int(time.time())
     test_framework.wait_until(lambda: node.getindexinfo("txindex")["txindex"]["synced"])
     test_framework.log.debug(f"Synced in {time.time() - sync_start} seconds")
+
+def add_quotes_for_cli(cli, text):
comments.body: Hmm, this is only an issue because  `hash_or_height` expects a JSON object, not a string (and a text without quotes is no valid JSON object), so regular string args don't need this. I think the current naming is confusing, maybe renaming the function "`convert_to_json_for_cli`" and calling `json.dumps(text)` inside instead of adding quotes (in case the cli is used) would be better to convey why this is done? Or is there a better solution?
